PM11:12am

Bottom line – a hawkish turn on inflation language is already priced in, and the FOMC probably does not want to lock in on four hikes this early in the year.

The FOMC will sound hawkish on baseline and dovish on risks. The hawkish baseline is a that the language on inflation needs a makeover. The dovish part is that there is likely to be some explicit reference to downside risks – otherwise there is nothing to balance the inflation language change.

With trepidation, I am going to make the case that the market already prices in hawkish Fed language and intentions as a baseline. Unless the Fed signals ‘Inflation Code Red’ (unlikely at a no-presser and in the absence of preparation), there is likely to be enough risk language to convey that there are reasonable circumstances when they would not hike. Hence, I see upside for equities and downside for USD on FOMC event risk.

PM11:16am

At their last meeting, the last reads on core and headline PCE were 1.5% and 1.7% respectively. Now they are 1.9% and 2.0%, so honesty now forces them to say something like “inflation is now running close to target”.

They will have a hard time repeating that “Inflation on a 12-month basis is expected to move up in coming months and to stabilize around the Committee's 2 percent objective over the medium term” because there is scarce room to move up without going beyond 2%.

Maybe they can say something like “both headline and core inflation are now approaching 2%”, and “Inflation on a 12-month basis is expected to stabilize around the Committee’s 2% objective”. Normally, you would view this as a hawkish shift, but much of this is already priced in and would not convey too much concern.

From a market perspective, start from the view that no one see five or more hikes this year. In March there was only one dot for more than four hikes. This is very important because it means that only 15bps is left to be priced in till you get to the full four hikes. (I think investors are underpricing the risk of five hikes, but my view doesn’t change market pricing.)

PM11:17am

Another 5bps added to end 2018 fed funds would price in a 60 percent chance of four hikes – with seven months and all downside political, economic and market risk compressed into a very limited amount of risk. Investors now price almost certainty that the FOMC will hike in June and September. The FOMC doesn’t have to say that they won’t hike – all they have to say is that there are risks on top of a generally positive picture.

From that perspective I think it is hard for 2018 fed funds to react much to the likely inflation rhetoric. Take it as a given that a no-Press Conference meeting is not where the Fed will open the door to the possibility of more than four hikes in 2018. (We may see some Fed speakers alluding to the possibility in coming weeks but I have a 24 hour time horizon now). They need to find some downside risks somewhere and they are likely to raise downside risks in some oblique fashion to balance the call to action that recent inflation numbers are signaling.

Bonus comment for reading this far -- I also expect AHE to come in on the soft side this month, largley for technical reasons, so if I am right on both FOMC and AHE views, equities look good, less so USD, and bond yields will come off as much as an equity rally permits.

Snap posted another conviction-testing quarter as a confluence of headwinds including a negative consumer reaction to the app redesign, marketer hesitation following the appearance of problematic ad content, as well as the programmatic transition of Lenses/Filters all contrived to deliver a shortfall versus consensus estimates. The historical problems Snap has had with its Android app were only compounded post the redesign which also drove a miss on DAUs as well. It hence appears that the ramp in monetization which was central to our thesis will be delayed into late 2H18 and SNAP shares now return to being a show-me story on user recovery as it hits the reset button on the redesign as well as the release of the completely rebuilt Android app by 3Q18. As shares have already retraced back almost all of the gains, we elect to maintain our Outperform rating for now given the upside potential but acknowledge that further patience may be required.

BE11:39am

The consensus values UMG at between €12bn-€40bn. If we assume a valuation of €20bn (or 20x EBITDA), disposing of 15% of equity would allow Vivendi to receive €3bn. As we detailed in our 23/03 note (‘Is a structuring deal with another agency in the offing? WPP?’), this cash could be used to expand the group's exposure to the advertising agency sector. When the Bolloré annual results were presented, Vincent Bolloré clearly referred to this market as priority. The prime target may be WPP. The idea might then be to use the cash from the UMG IPO to acquire a sizable stake in WPP. Based on WPP's market capitalisation (~18bn), Vivendi could acquire ~17% of the capital or more with leveraging. The aim could then be to merge Havas and WPP, and increase the stake with the intention of working towards controlling the new entity. Reducing the stake in UMG (up to 51%) could finance this increase.

A 20% placing could raise €3.5bn which added to the proceeds from Ubisoft exit would give Vivendi $6-7bn to spend on acquisitions.

In terms of further expansion in videogames, Vivendi would probably be happy to acquire control via a 20-25% stake (e.g. Telecom Italia). Nintendo (€60bn mkt cap) seems too large, but it doesn’t have major shareholder. EA (€36bn mkt cap), TTWO (11.4bn), ZNGA (€2.6bn) and Bethesda are all potential targets. Glu Mobile (0.6bn) could probably be good complement to Gameloft. Many other videogames companies have management with significant position (e.g. Capcom, Konami, Square Enix, Bandai Namco), but that is unlikely to stop Bollore’ if size and valuation allows.

BE12:01pm

Management is guiding to FY18 EBITDA of £470-495m, which is 2% below consensus at the midpoint (NSe and consensus £491m). This guidance includes additional investment in Australia (c.£10m) to take advantage of the potential disruption facing competitors (i.e. Stars' acquisition of Crownbet and WH Australia). Despite a slowdown in growth, PPB still has #1 market share in the UK, is the third largest listed online operator in the world, is well diversified from a geographical perspective, and has a strong balance sheet (c.£1bn firepower). The shares have come under pressure, down 20% ytd amid potential regulatory headwinds (UK and Australia), a 6% earnings downgrade from the proposed increase in marketing and price investment and caution over the newly appointed management. Our grey sky valuation of £73 is 2% above the current share price.

BE12:02pm

There are positives and negatives from this morning’s update. The revenue performance during Q1 will come as a surprise, but it has to be viewed in the context of a number of one-off factors namely weather and Australian sporting results. The underlying performances in Australia and the US remain positive. Without poor weather, Retail would have delivered its usual solid performance. In terms of Online Europe, the performance remains somewhat subdued, but again racing cancellations were an impact. The return to growth in February and March for gaming, along with increased product usage at PP in March (cash-out and in-running), could represent early signs of a turnaround in this divisions fortunes. We are likely to reduce our FY18 EBITDA forecasts by 1-2% from £494m currently. This will bring us broadly in line with the mid-point of management’s guidance range. Given the headwinds (Q1 weather impact, adverse Q1 Australian sporting results & increase investment in this market, and a weaker Grand National results wise yoy) the guidance range should offer some comfort. In addition, the share buyback should be well received.
